original_data.question: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with a fever. She developed worsening malaise and diaphoresis over the past 48 hours. Her maximum temperature was 102°F (38.9°C) taken the night before presentation. Her past medical history is notable for major depressive disorder, obesity, fibromyalgia, and severe tension headaches. She previously took paroxetine for a 2-month trial but switched to citalopram 6 months ago as she did not feel like paroxetine was adequately helping her symptoms. Her mood has been stable on her current dose of citalopram. She takes ibuprofen for her headaches but previously borrowed a friend’s headache medication when her headaches became very severe. Of note, she has been trying to lose weight and recently started taking an amino acid supplement at the suggestion of her nephew who is a nutritionist. She is also trying out a new low-carbohydrate diet. She works as a nurse at a local primary care clinic. Her temperature is 101.5°F (38.6°C), blood pressure is 144/80 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 22/min. She is diaphoretic and shivering. Patellar and brachioradialis reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Tone is increased in her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Rapid dorsiflexion of her right ankle elicits 3 beats of clonus. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. A basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely inciting factor for this patient’s condition?

model_response:
This patient’s presentation is most consistent with serotonin syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by altered mental status, neuromuscular abnormalities, autonomic hyperactivity, and hyperthermia. The syndrome can occur with therapeutic use of serotonergic medications or with ingestion of serotonin-elevating substances such as certain herbal supplements, antidepressants, and opiates. The inciting factor in this case is the change in medication from paroxetine to citalopram. Both medications are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), but the potency of citalopram is significantly less than paroxetine. The change in medication is likely to have caused an increase in serotonergic activity, leading to serotonin syndrome. The syndrome is also likely worsened by her increased carbohydrate intake and weight loss, as both are associated with increased tryptophan intake. Tryptophan is a precursor in the synthesis of serotonin. Decreased carbohydrate intake and weight loss can lead to increased tryptophan intake and subsequently increased serotonin production. The syndrome can occur in individuals who abuse illicit drugs such as ecstasy (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine; MDMA), which acts to increase serotonergic activity. The syndrome is also associated with surreptitious opiate abuse, as certain opiates (such as meperidine and tramadol) can increase serotonergic activity. The syndrome is not associated with overdose of citalopram, as the medication has a very large therapeutic index and significant overdose would be required to cause serotonin syndrome.


Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A sudden unforeseen crisis that requires immediate action.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Profuse sweating.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The largest possible quantity or degree.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
An affective disorder manifested by either a dysphoric mood or loss of interest or pleasure in usual activities. The mood disturbance is prominent and relatively persistent.

A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the recommended standards, usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX, a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).

A common nonarticular rheumatic syndrome characterized by myalgia and multiple points of focal muscle tenderness to palpation (trigger points). Muscle pain is typically aggravated by inactivity or exposure to cold. This condition is often associated with general symptoms, such as sleep disturbances, fatigue, stiffness, HEADACHES, and occasionally DEPRESSION. There is significant overlap between fibromyalgia and the chronic fatigue syndrome (FATIGUE SYNDROME, CHRONIC). Fibromyalgia may arise as a primary or secondary disease process. It is most frequent in females aged 20 to 50 years. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1494-95)
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
A feeling of mental or emotional strain or suspense.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
A serotonin uptake inhibitor that is effective in the treatment of depression.

Works about pre-planned studies of the safety, efficacy, or optimum dosage schedule (if appropriate) of one or more diagnostic, therapeutic, or prophylactic drugs, devices, or techniques selected according to predetermined criteria of eligibility and observed for predefined evidence of favorable and unfavorable effects. This concept includes clinical trials conducted both in the U.S. and in other countries.

A furancarbonitrile that is one of the SELECTIVE SEROTONIN REUPTAKE INHIBITORS used as an antidepressant. The drug is also effective in reducing ethanol uptake in alcoholics and is used in depressed patients who also suffer from TARDIVE DYSKINESIA in preference to tricyclic antidepressants, which aggravate dyskinesia.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A serotonin uptake inhibitor that is effective in the treatment of depression.
A relatively temporary state of feeling.
The quality of being free from change or variation or not taking part readily in chemical change.
A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.

A furancarbonitrile that is one of the SELECTIVE SEROTONIN REUPTAKE INHIBITORS used as an antidepressant. The drug is also effective in reducing ethanol uptake in alcoholics and is used in depressed patients who also suffer from TARDIVE DYSKINESIA in preference to tricyclic antidepressants, which aggravate dyskinesia.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
The uncritical acceptance of an idea or plan of action.
A son of your brother or sister.
Persons specially trained in NUTRITION SCIENCES.
A diet that contains limited amounts of CARBOHYDRATES. This is in distinction to a regular DIET.

Professionals qualified by graduation from an accredited school of nursing and by passage of a national licensing examination to practice nursing. They provide services to patients requiring assistance in recovering or maintaining their physical or mental health.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Pertaining to, characterized by, or promoting sweating, e.g. procedure or an agent that promotes sweating.
Involuntary contraction or twitching of the muscles. It is a physiologic method of heat production in man and other mammals.
The flat, triangular bone situated at the anterior part of the KNEE.

A muscle that originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts into the styloid process of the radius; it enables flexion of the elbow and assists with pronation and supination of the forearm.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
In a place or position that is higher.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.
An assessment of joint flexibility that measures the movement of a body part bending towards its dorsal surface, in number of degrees.

A group of cardiac arrhythmias in which the cardiac contractions are not initiated at the SINOATRIAL NODE. They include both atrial and ventricular premature beats, and are also known as extra or ectopic heartbeats. Their frequency is increased in heart diseases.

A form of involuntary muscular movement characterized by alternating contractions and relaxation in rapid succession. In the context of reflex testing, the ability to elicit clonus indicates injury to the nerve tracts above the point at which the reflex was initiated.
The aperture in the iris through which light passes.
The shape of a circle.
A presence finding used to indicate that the specified component / analyte reacted with the reagent above the reliably measurable limit of the performed test.
The chemical reactions and pathways by which individual cells transform chemical substances. [GOC:go_curators]
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
